title: Spatial Analysis Using Raster Data
description: Species richness of cetaceans along the California coast.
contents:
Cetacean Data
Read in cetacean data using raster::stack() and explore using the plot() function.

hide
my_files <- list.files(path = "ca_cetaceans", full.names = TRUE)

cetaceans <- raster::stack(my_files)

plot(cetaceans)




Figure 1: Figure 1. Species abundance along the California costline. Higher levels of presence are shown in green and lower levels shown in pink.



Presence and Threshold
Create a function to Set a threshold for the presence of the species at 0.6, and assign a value for 1 if present or 0 if not not.

hide
is_present <- function(x, thresh = .6) {
  y <- ifelse(x >= thresh, 1, NA)
  return(y)
}

cetaceans_present <- calc(cetaceans, fun = is_present)

plot(cetaceans_present)




Figure 2: Figure 2. Presence of species on the California coast. Areas colored in yellow have an abundance higher than 0.6. Areas that are not colored in are either lower than 0.6 or did not show any signs of named species in that cell.



Finalized plot of species richness

hide
cetaceans_df <- raster::rasterToPoints(cetaceans_present) %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = Balaenoptera_acutorostrata:Ziphius_cavirostris,
               names_to = "species",
               values_to = "present") %>%
  group_by(x, y) %>% 
  replace_na(list(present = 0)) %>% 
  filter(present == 1) %>% 
  count(present)

world <- ne_countries(scale='medium',returnclass = 'sf')


ggplot() +
  geom_raster(data = cetaceans_df, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = n)) +
  geom_sf(data = world) +
  coord_sf(expand = 0, xlim = c(-125, -115), ylim = c(32, 38)) +
  theme_void() +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = c("lightblue1", "aquamarine4")) +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.85, 0.8),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill = "gray75", linetype = "solid"),
        legend.key.size = unit(0.5, "cm"),
        legend.key.width = unit(0.5,"cm"),
        legend.margin=margin(t = 0.2, b = 0.2, l = 0.2, r = 0.2, unit='cm'),
        plot.margin = unit(c(0,0,0,0), units = "cm")) +
  labs(fill = "Species Richness") +
  annotation_scale(pad_x = unit(7.5, "cm"), aes(unit_category = "imperial", style = "bar")) +
  annotation_north_arrow(height = unit(1.5, "cm"), width = unit(1.5, "cm"), style = north_arrow_nautical())




Figure 3: Figure 3. Species richness of cetaceans on the California coast. Areas colored in darker green have higher richness, and lighter areas have lower richness.

title: Welcome.
contents: This part of my site is intended to display some of my previous work. I’ve done work and am comfortable with R, R Shiny, RMarkdown, ArcGIS, and of course, the {postcards} and {distill} packages. I hope you have fun exploring, I had fun creating.

title: Binomial Logistic Regression
description: An analysis of different palmetto species
contents:
hide

palmetto <- read_csv("palmetto.csv") %>% 
  mutate(species = as.factor(species))



Section 1
Graph 1.


hide

spp_labs <- c("Serenoa repens", "Sabal etonia")
names(spp_labs) <- c("1", "2")
  
ggplot(data = palmetto, aes(x = width, y = length)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species), alpha = 0.5) +
  facet_wrap(~species,
             labeller = labeller(species = spp_labs)) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  scale_color_manual(values = c("chartreuse4", "yellowgreen")) +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        panel.border = element_rect(fill = NA),
        strip.text.x = element_text(face = "italic")) +
  labs(x = "Widest width of the canopy, perpindicular to length (cm)", y = "Widest length of the canopy (cm)")




Figure 1: Figure 1. Comparing length and width of two species of palmetto Sabal etonia and Serenoa repens. Serenoa repens is shown in dark green and Sabal etonia is shown in light green.



Both Sabal etonia and Serenoa repens seem to cluster around the same width to length ratio, but Sabal etonia tends towards being slightly longer at shorter widths.
Graph 2.


hide

ggplot(data = palmetto, aes(x = green_lvs, y = height)) +
  geom_jitter(aes(color = green_lvs),
              alpha = 0.5) +
  facet_wrap(~species,
             labeller = labeller(species = spp_labs)) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  scale_color_gradientn(colors = c("greenyellow","chartreuse4", "olivedrab4")) +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        panel.border = element_rect(fill = NA),
        strip.text.x = element_text(face = "italic")) +
  labs(x = "Green Leaves (n)", y = "Maximum height (cm)")




Figure 2: Figure 2. Comparison of number of green leaves versus height in two species of plametto Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia. Lower numbers of leaves are represented in light green and higher numbers in dark green.



Sabal etonia produces fewer leaves in general, but it produces more leaves when it is a shorter palmetto than Serenoa repens.
Section 2


hide

palmetto_blr <- glm(species ~ height + length + width + green_lvs,
                            data = palmetto, 
                            family = "binomial") 

# summary(palmetto_blr)
# levels(palmetto$species)
# serenoa repens is coded as 0, sabal etonia is coded as 1

palmetto_tidy <- palmetto_blr %>% 
  broom::tidy() %>% 
  select(estimate, std.error, p.value) %>%
  mutate_if(is.numeric, funs(as.character(signif(., 3))))

rownames(palmetto_tidy) <- c("Intercept",
                  "Height (cm)",
                  "Length (cm)",
                  "Width (cm)",
                  "Green Leaves (n)")


  kableExtra::kable(palmetto_tidy,
                    col.names = c("Coefficient",
                                  "Standard Error",
                                  "p-value"),
                    caption = "_Table 1._ Binomial logistic regression of _serenoa repens_ and *sabal etonia* in which _sabal etonia_ is the reference level.") %>%
# Column names - can't change row names in kable.
  kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped",
                full_width = F,
                position = "center") %>%
# Full width (F), centered table.
  kableExtra::add_header_above(bold = TRUE,
                   line = TRUE,
                   c("Binomial Logistic Regression for _Serenoa repens_ and _Sabal etonia_" = 4))



Table 1: Table 1. Binomial logistic regression of serenoa repens and sabal etonia in which sabal etonia is the reference level.



Binomial Logistic Regression for Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia





Coefficient


Standard Error


p-value


Intercept


3.23


0.142


3.42e-114


Height (cm)


-0.0292


0.00231


8.69e-37


Length (cm)


0.0458


0.00187


3.73e-133


Width (cm)


0.0394


0.0021


1.05e-78


Green Leaves (n)


-1.91


0.0389


0


Section 3


hide

blr_fitted <- palmetto_blr %>% 
  broom::augment(type.predict = "response") %>% 
  mutate(predicted = ifelse(.fitted >= 0.5, "sabal", "serenoa")) %>% 
  mutate(correct = ifelse(predicted == "sabal" & species == 2, "predicted_correctly",
                          ifelse(predicted == "serenoa" & species == 1, "predicted_correctly", "predicted_incorrectly"))) 

palmetto_table <- blr_fitted %>% 
  count(correct, species) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = correct, 
              values_from = n) %>% 
  mutate(percent = (predicted_correctly / (predicted_correctly + predicted_incorrectly)) * 100) %>% 
  mutate(across(is.numeric, ~ round(., 2))) %>% 
  mutate(species = c("Serenoa repens",
                   "Sabal etonia")) %>%
  kableExtra::kable(col.names = c("Species",
                      "Predicted correctly",
                      "Predicted incorrectly",
                      "Predicted correctly (%)"),
                caption = "_Table 2._ Predictions of _Serenoa repens_ and _Sabal etonia_ using bionomial logistic regression. Percent predicted correctly is the percentage of observations that the model correctly classified as the species that was observed") %>%
# Column names - can't change row names in kable.
  kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped",
                full_width = F,
                position = "center") %>%
# Full width (F), centered table.
  kableExtra::add_header_above(bold = TRUE,
                   line = TRUE,
                   c("Prediction for _Serenoa repens_ and _Sabal etonia_ using binomial logistic regression" = 4))


palmetto_table



Table 2: Table 2. Predictions of Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia using bionomial logistic regression. Percent predicted correctly is the percentage of observations that the model correctly classified as the species that was observed



Prediction for Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia using binomial logistic regression



Species


Predicted correctly


Predicted incorrectly


Predicted correctly (%)


Serenoa repens


5548


564


90.77


Sabal etonia


5701


454


92.62

title: PCA Analysis
description: Analysis of nutrients in Cheese using a PCA biplot
contents:
Introduction
This data explores different types of cheese, comparing them on the basis of fat, protein, sugar, carbohydrates, fiber and calories. Data includes nutrient information from the USDA, but was filtered to only show comparisons between a few variables. This data is looked at on a PCA biplot, to see patterns in nutrients in cheese, and look for clusters of data to then be able to explore these comparisons further. Data taken from FoodData Central.

Read in and clean data



PCA Biplot



Summary
This biplot shows that 42.88% of the variation in the data can be seen on the principal component 1 axis (PC1), and 21.04% on PC2. In addition, other takeaways are:
In cheese, fat and calories are highly related, they are nearly pointing the same direction and their arrow lengths are also almost the same. The differences in the lengths of the arrows mean that there is slightly less variation explained for fat than calories along PC1.
There is a cluster of cheeses that exist between protein, fat and energy. If I were to explore this data further, I would want to look into what those cheeses are and potentially make further conclusions about how and why they are grouped together.
Protein and sugar have a negative correlation, shown by the arrows pointing opposite directions.
Fiber and carbohydrates have nearly a no relation to each other at all, shown by the 90 degree angle between their arrows.

title: Analysis of Sierra Amphibians
contents:
Read in the data


sierra_df <- readxl::read_xlsx("sierra_amphibians.xlsx")



Task 1.1
A graph of total mountain yellow-legged frog (Rana muscosa) count each year across all water bodies, by life stage excluding the ‘EggMass’ level.


ramu_df <- sierra_df %>% 
  filter(amphibian_species == "RAMU") %>% 
  filter(!amphibian_life_stage == "EggMass") %>% 
  mutate(survey_date = lubridate::ymd(survey_date)) %>% 
  mutate(year = year(survey_date)) %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  count(amphibian_life_stage, wt = amphibian_number)
#wt = amphibian number essentially performs the uncount function within the count function

ramu_plot <- ggplot(ramu_df, aes(x = year, y = n)) +
  geom_col(aes(fill = year), color = "black", show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colours = c("gold","darkgoldenrod3", "darkolivegreen4") ) +
  facet_wrap(~amphibian_life_stage, scales = "free") + #without scales = "free" the numbers are a bit hard to see for the lifestages other than tadpole
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = expression(paste("Count of mountain yellow-legged frog (", italic("Rana muscosa"), ") by lifestage")),
       x = NULL,
       y = "Count") +
  theme(panel.border = element_rect(colour = "black", fill=NA, size=0.5))



Task 1.2
A column graph containing total counts (over all years of the study) of combined adult and subadult endangered mountain yellow-legged frogs (Rana muscosa) observed in the 5 lakes with the greatest total observed counts.


lake_df <- sierra_df %>% 
  filter(amphibian_species == "RAMU") %>% 
  filter(!amphibian_life_stage %in% c("EggMass", "Tadpole")) %>% 
  mutate(lake_number = paste("Lake", lake_id)) %>% 
  group_by(lake_number) %>% 
  count(amphibian_life_stage, wt = amphibian_number) 
#wt = amphibian number essentially performs the uncount function within the count function

lake_df_top_5 <- lake_df %>% 
  count(lake_number, wt = n) %>% 
  ungroup(lake_number) %>% 
  rename(amphibian_count = n) %>% 
  slice_max(amphibian_count, n = 5)

lake_df_lifestage <- lake_df %>% 
  inner_join(lake_df_top_5) %>% 
  rename(lifestage_count = n) 

lake_plot <- ggplot(lake_df_lifestage, aes(y = lifestage_count, x = fct_reorder(lake_number, lifestage_count))) +
  geom_bar(position = "stack", stat = "identity", aes(fill = amphibian_life_stage)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("darkgoldenrod3", "darkolivegreen4", breaks = c("Adult", "SubAdult"))) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(fill = "Life-stage",
       title = "Lakes with the highest numbers of mountain yellow-legged frog",
       x = NULL,
       y = "Count")+
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.85,0.25))+
  theme(panel.border = element_rect(colour = "black", fill=NA, size=0.5))
  
#lake_plot



Final plot for mountain yellow-legged frog using patchwork


ramu_plot / lake_plot




Figure 1: Figure 1. Plot of counts of mountain yellow legged frogs, by year and life-stage, as well as by top 5 lakes with the highest total counts of adults in subadults. In the upper plots, the different colors of bars display different years. In the lower plot, green depicts total counts through all years for subadults and yellow depicts total counts through all years for adults in each lake surveyed
